title: ENG09_pt 1: 2.5 Culture: Who are we? | SVHS

mainContent.text:
2.5 Culture: Who are we?

        Completion requirements
        



Culture

Defining "I" (personal identity) is tough enough.  But what about defining "we" as a culture?  It's a daunting task, especially for a young person.
Culture is an umbrella term comprised of many moving parts: personal and family values, community beliefs, education and language, even dress and food customs.  Most of these are taught to us directly; others, however, are invisible
    and taken for granted.  We often appreciate our home culture, ironically, only after we leave home and enter into a new culture.
You've heard of the Shrek "Onion Theory"?  Think of your identity as an onion with many layers.  On the outermost "skin" is your larger community (national culture).  Another layer in is your neighborhood (local culture). 
    And then there's your family (home culture).  And then there's your core social and emotional values.  Where do your beliefs and attitudes come from?  It's a complex exchange between all the cultural layers.  
Take a look at this diagram:

There are three kinds of conversations we've all had: 


    entry conversations about work, family, history, and education.
    investigative questions about how we make choices and internalize values personally.
    conversion discussions about core beliefs initially influenced by culture but later changed through crisis and confrontation.



Needless to say, it's a complicated process!
Watch the following videos to learn more:





Reading:
Social Identity Theory
